pageData.text: In this activity, students explore disease transmission by sampling <button class='glossary-text'>fomites</button> for the presence of <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> and growing the collected bacteria and fungi in Petri dishes. Students will also model the spread of such microbes as vectors of disease. Students will make predictions about the amount of microbes present in their surroundings, inoculate their samples onto growth <button class='glossary-text'>media</button>, incubate the <button class='glossary-text'>cultures</button>, and observe the growth of the microbes present. Then, with the help of volunteers, students will use an acid solution and pH indicator to simulate how diseases spread.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:

Paper towels
Glass or plastic container for cleanup and disposal of Petri dishes
Microwave
Oven mitt or pot holder
Pen or pencil
White paper

7 activity participants

text: Make predictions about microbial growth.
Perform an experiment using a control and a single variable.

Obtain samples of <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> from the environment and inoculate <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> plates using <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic technique</button>.
Observe and report on growth of microbes from different <button class='glossary-text'>fomites</button>.
Model how microbes act as vectors of disease.

pageData.text: Microbial biofilms, such as those that form on implanted medical devices, are responsible for many chronic infections and can be very difficult to treat. These biofilms consist of diverse microbial communities living in close proximity to each other. They create a slime-like matrix and communicate through quorum sensing. Not only is this matrix difficult to penetrate with antibiotics, but some members of the biofilm may also have antibiotic-resistant  genes and can offer the community additional protection against chemotherapeutics.

It is very difficult to <button class='glossary-text'>culture</button> <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> that live in biofilms. However, a new technique has been developed that allows researchers to investigate complex microbial colonies and their interactions with the host. Researchers at UC Santa Cruz are using imaging mass spectrometry to investigate the Hawaiian bobtail squid (Euprymna scolopes) and its symbiotic bioluminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri<sup class='bodysubscript'>1</sup>. This technique allows researchers to study novel protein interactions between the microbial colonies and their host. This research may not only shed light on the squid/bacteria symbiosis but may also provide insight into biofilm formation on implanted medical devices.

1Zink, K. et al. (2021). A small molecule coordinates symbiotic behaviors in a host organ. mBio. 12:2.
https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/mbio.03637-20

pageData.desc: A Hawaiian bobtail squid on the ocean floor.
pageData.altText: A Hawaiian bobtail squid on the ocean floor.

pageData.text:
Bobtail squid by Christian Gloor available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://flickr.com/photos/76738608@N08/13909489472

are organisms and infectious particles too small to be seen with the unaided eye. The bacteria and archaea are prokaryotic microbes, single-celled  organisms that lack a nucleus. Other microbes, such as protozoa, algae, and fungi, are eukaryotic, and they have a nucleus. Still others are non-cellular, infectious particles—much simpler than any living cell, but able to infect cellular life forms in order to reproduce. These include viruses, which consist of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) enclosed in a protein coat, sometimes surrounded by a membranous envelope. Prions are infectious protein particles, and viroids are composed only of RNA.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of microbe classification. Microbes can be acellular or cellular. Acellular microbes can either contain nucleic acids (DNA/RNA) or not. Acellular microbes with nucleic acids include bacteriophage that infect bacteria, viruses that infect eukaryotic cells, and viroids that infect plants. Acellular microbes without nucleic acids include prions that infect animals such as humans, cows and sheep. Cellular microbes may or may not have a nucleus. Cellular microbes without a nucleus are prokaryotes. Pro meaning before and kary meaning nucleus. They are unicellular and lack membrane-bound organelles. Examples of prokaryotes include archaea and bacteria. Cellular microbes with a nucleus are eukaryotes. Eu meaning true and kary meaning nucleus. They have membrane-bound organelles. Examples of eukaryotes include algae, protozoa, fungi, plants and animals.
pageData.desc: Figure 1: A diagram of microbe classification. Microbes can be acellular or cellular. Acellular microbes can either contain nucleic acids (DNA/RNA) or not. Acellular microbes with nucleic acids include bacteriophage that infect bacteria, viruses that infect eukaryotic cells, and viroids that infect plants. Acellular microbes without nucleic acids include prions that infect animals such as humans, cows and sheep. Cellular microbes may or may not have a nucleus. Cellular microbes without a nucleus are prokaryotes. Pro meaning before and kary meaning nucleus. They are unicellular and lack membrane-bound organelles. Examples of prokaryotes include archaea and bacteria. Cellular microbes with a nucleus are eukaryotes. Eu meaning true and kary meaning nucleus. They have membrane-bound organelles. Examples of eukaryotes include algae, protozoa, fungi, plants and animals.

pageData.text: Microbes are incredibly diverse. The bacteria alone include untold thousands of species. Microbes use a wide variety of different life styles to survive in their environments. Most are <button class='glossary-text'>free-living</button>, meaning they do not depend on a host organism for survival. These microbes may exist as producers (or autotrophs) in the food chain, generating their own food, for example, by photosynthesis. Others are consumers (or heterotrophs), such as <button class='glossary-text'>saprophytes</button>, which decompose dead organic material to obtain nutrients for their own growth. Some heterotrophic microbes even prey on smaller microbes. A much smaller proportion of heterotrophic microbes are <button class='glossary-text'>parasites</button>, which obtain nutrients from larger host organisms. When microbes cause disease, they are said to be <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>. Some microbes are <button class='glossary-text'>opportunistic</button> pathogens; i.e., they are generally free-living, but can cause disease if given the opportunity.

Diseases can be spread in different ways, including contact with contaminated objects or air, person to person, or another manner that involves exposure to <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Fomites</button> are inanimate objects that transmit infectious diseases from <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> found on their surfaces. When a human or animal comes in contact with a fomite, there is potential for the pathogens on the object’s surface to infect the organism. Fomite transmission relies on factors such as the type of pathogen, the quantity of the pathogen required for infection, environmental conditions, and the porosity of the fomite’s surface.

Samples obtained from a particular fomite are likely to contain a mixture of several different species. Because the human body is inhabited by communities of microbes, it is very important that is used when sampling for microbes. Aseptic technique is a set of procedures for handling microbes that is aimed at avoiding contamination and includes the preparation of (microbe-free) and of work areas to greatly reduce the number of microbes present. Unless aseptic technique is employed, accidental contamination of the sample with the individual’s microbes, or microbes present in airborne dust, may occur.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of using aseptic technique to handle microbes?

options.text: It prevents the individual from contaminating a sample with their own microbes.
It prevents microbes from becoming airborne pathogens.
It limits the spread of an infection if the individual is exposed to a microbial sample.
It facilitates microbial growth when incubating at room temperature.
It distinguishes free-living microbes from parasitic microbes in a sample.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Aseptic technique is aimed at avoiding contamination of a sample by microbes from the environment, such as the individual’s microbes or microbes in airborne dust.

pageData.question: Which of the following is a practice consistent with aseptic technique?

options.text: disinfecting the work area with a bleach solution
having a fan blow over the microbes as they grow
sampling a microbial community inhabiting a pond
growing microbial samples in a hot oven

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Disinfecting work areas is part of using aseptic technique.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Because the human body is inhabited by communities of microbes, it is very important that aseptic technique is used when obtaining an environmental sample. Aseptic technique is a set of procedures for handling microbes that is aimed at avoiding contamination and includes the preparation of sterile (microbe-free) media and disinfection of work areas to greatly reduce the number of microbes present. Unless aseptic technique is employed, accidental contamination of the sample with the individual’s microbes, or microbes present in airborne dust, may occur.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Because the human body is inhabited by communities of microbes, it is very important that aseptic technique is used when obtaining an environmental sample. Aseptic technique is a set of procedures for handling microbes that is aimed at avoiding contamination and includes the preparation of sterile (microbe-free) media and disinfection of work areas to greatly reduce the number of microbes present. Unless aseptic technique is employed, accidental contamination of the sample with the individual’s microbes, or microbes present in airborne dust, may occur.

pageData.text: collected from the environment must be provided with all the resources they need to survive. Moisture, nutrients, and temperature are just a few factors that must be considered when cultivating various types of microbes. Determining the conditions needed to grow a particular microbe can be very challenging. Indeed, many microbes are currently considered to be because no one has yet discovered how to recreate the conditions necessary for their growth. One important component of culturing microbes is the (plural, ), the substrate within or on which the microbes will grow. Media may be liquid, or they may contain a solidifying agent, such as . Nutrient agar, which will be used in this exercise, is considered a general-purpose medium, because many (but not all) types of microbes can grow on it.

After adding microbes to—or <button class='glossary-text'>inoculating</button>—the medium, the resulting <button class='glossary-text'>culture</button> must then be placed in favorable growth conditions. Some microbes grow best at warmer temperatures, such as those found within the human body. Others prefer cooler temperatures, such as those found deep in the soil. In this investigation, cultures will be maintained at room temperature, which can vary widely, but is generally considered to be approximately 21°C (70°F).

You might expect that a microscope is needed to observe . Surprisingly, this is often not the case. —biologists who specialize in the study of microbes—perform many observations, meaning that they use the unaided eye. In this exercise, macroscopic observations will be made of growth resulting from the inoculation of samples onto nutrient maintained at room temperature. Some mounds of growth may appear and increase in size over time. These are termed (Figure 2). A colony is an aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely-adhering cells. Certain microbes, particularly among the bacteria and fungi, will form colonies when they are thinly spread on nutrient agar. Colonies may offer some clues as to the identity of the microbes in the sample. For example, certain species of fungi will produce fuzzy-looking colonies, whereas bacteria frequently generate colonies that are relatively smooth in appearance. If a particularly rich sample of microbes that grow well under the conditions of this investigation is obtained, the growth may be so abundant that it is not possible to distinguish individual colonies.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: An agar plate with many small, circular colonies present.
pageData.desc: Figure 2: An agar plate with many small, circular colonies present.

pageData.question: In this investigation, what type of observations will you take of your microbial samples?

feedbackData.text: In this investigation, macroscopic observations will be made of growth resulting from the inoculation of samples onto nutrient agar maintained at room temperature.

pageData.question: After growing a sample of microbes on an agar plate, you discover a fuzzy substance covering the entirety of the medium’s surface. Which of the following is the best interpretation of this type of growth?

options.text: There is abundant growth on the plate.
Only bacterial colonies are growing on the plate.
The incubation temperature was too low.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Abundant microbial growth may prevent you from distinguishing individual colonies.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A colony is an aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely adhering cells. Certain microbes, particularly bacteria and fungi, will form colonies when they are thinly spread on nutrient agar. Colonies may offer some clues as to the identity of the microbes in the sample. If a particularly rich sample of microbes, the growth may be so abundant that it is not possible to distinguish individual colonies. In this investigation, macroscopic observations will be made of growth resulting from the inoculation of samples onto nutrient agar maintained at room temperature; therefore, you will not need a microscope.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, prepare a disinfectant. Then, heat and pour the agar tubes into plates and allow the plates to cool. Next, draw quadrants on 3 plates. In activity 1, inoculate the control plate with a sterile swab. Then, select your sample sites and label 1 quadrant with each sample site name. Next, culture each sample site and inoculate the quadrant with the sample. Repeat this for 12 sample locations. Then, cover your plates with parafilm, invert and store them. Finally, photograph the plates each day for 5 days. In activity 2, prepare 1 cup of acid and 7 cups of water. Then, randomize the cup order and distribute them to the gathered participants. Next, partner your participants and have them exchange fluids with their partner. Repeat this 3 times. Then, add universal indicator to the cups and measure the pH. Finally, map out the fluid exchanges and determine patient zero.
pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, prepare a disinfectant. Then, heat and pour the agar tubes into plates and allow the plates to cool. Next, draw quadrants on 3 plates. In activity 1, inoculate the control plate with a sterile swab. Then, select your sample sites and label 1 quadrant with each sample site name. Next, culture each sample site and inoculate the quadrant with the sample. Repeat this for 12 sample locations. Then, cover your plates with parafilm, invert and store them. Finally, photograph the plates each day for 5 days. In activity 2, prepare 1 cup of acid and 7 cups of water. Then, randomize the cup order and distribute them to the gathered participants. Next, partner your participants and have them exchange fluids with their partner. Repeat this 3 times. Then, add universal indicator to the cups and measure the pH. Finally, map out the fluid exchanges and determine patient zero.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Hydrochloric acid is a corrosive material. Use this material near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Bogen Universal Indicator Solution is a flammable liquid and vapor, and causes damage to organs if ingested.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work space with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is most likely to be a fomite?

Which are producers in the food chain?

What ratio of bleach to water should you use to make the surface disinfectant for this investigation?
Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself for this investigation?

when their growing conditions cannot be recreated
when they are collected from the environment as endospores

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activity.
Obtain all materials.
Wash and dry your hands thoroughly, and put on PPE (safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron).
Create a 10% bleach solution to use as surface disinfectant. Measure 9 parts water to 1 part bleach (for example 900 mL  water and 100 mL bleach). Always wear PPE while handling bleach.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Clean the work area where you will pour your nutrient <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> plates and disinfect it by applying a 10% bleach solution with a paper towel. Allow to air-dry (this will take approximately 2 minutes) as this increases the effectiveness of the disinfectant. Watch the following video on how to properly disinfect a surface:
Caution: Make sure to loosen the caps, or pressure may build up in the bottles when heating, possibly causing an explosion hazard.
Slightly loosen the cap of a nutrient agar bottle (to allow steam to escape when heating).

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Place a paper towel in the microwave. Place the bottle on the paper towel and warm it up in 5-second intervals. This step is very important to ensure the does not explode in the microwave. Use an oven mitt or pot holder to take the test tube with media out every 5 seconds and gently swirl the media in the bottle..

Caution: To swirl the media, using an oven mitt or pot holder, tighten the cap, and turn the bottle back and forth. If the media has not completely melted, loosen the cap again and microwave it for another 5 seconds. Repeat this process until the media is completely melted, continuously keeping an eye on the media to avoid any explosions.
Allow the bottle to cool slightly before pouring the <button class='glossary-text'>medium</button> onto the plate. The medium should still be liquid, but the bottle should not be too hot to handle.
Caution: Do not place the bottles in an ice bath or refrigerator in an attempt to speed the cooling process.

Place a Petri dish on the prepared work surface. When cool, remove the cap from the bottle of melted nutrient agar, and lift the cover of the Petri dish just enough to pour in some of the medium. The plate should be about ⅓ to ½ full. You may have some medium remaining in the bottle (Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Photograph of cooled, melted nutrient agar being poured into a Petri dish with the lid lifted.
pageData.desc: Figure 3: Photograph of cooled, melted nutrient agar being poured into a Petri dish with the lid lifted.

pageData.text: While working, hold the agar tube tilted at a 45° angle to exclude dust.
Immediately replace the Petri dish lid.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Allow at least 30 minutes for the plate to set. Do not disturb the plate during this time.
Repeat Steps 5–10 with the remaining nutrient agar bottles.

Flip three of the agar plates so that they are lid-side down. On the side of the plate facing up, draw two perpendicular lines across the plate to divide the surface into four quadrants. Do this for each of the three upside down plates.
Dispose of the agar bottles and gloves in the garbage. Wash and dry your hands.

In Activity 1, you will select 12 sites in and around your residence from which to sample <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button>. You will then <button class='glossary-text'>inoculate</button> <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> plates with these samples, as well as create a control plate. You will observe your plates for any microbial growth over the course of 5 days.
Wash your hands and put on gloves.

To prepare the control plate, remove a swab from its packaging and open the lid of a nutrient plate just enough to insert the swab and swipe it in a zig-zag fashion across the surface of the agar (Figure 4). Label this plate “control” by writing on the bottom of the dish with the grease pencil. Discard the swab in the trash.
Caution: Avoid gouging the agar with the swab.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A swab streaking the surface of agar in a petri dish
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A swab streaking the surface of agar in a petri dish

pageData.text: Select twelve different sample sites.

Locations likely to yield large quantities of <button class='glossary-text'>microbes</button> include bathroom faucets, doorknobs, drinking fountains, bottoms of backpacks or purses, coins and paper currency, plant leaves, phones, stairway handrails, and computer mice and keyboards.
Caution: To reduce the risk of cultivating human , avoid sampling sites such as toilet seats, soles of shoes, nose or throat, or bodily fluids.

Label one of the quadrants on the bottom of a nutrient agar plate with the source of your first sample using the grease pencil. Write your label along the edge of the plate so the majority of the quadrant is still easily visible (Figure 5).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Diagram of a petri dish sectioned into four quadrants with one of the quadrants labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram of a petri dish sectioned into four quadrants with one of the quadrants labeled

pageData.text: Obtain the first sample.

Consider how you will inoculate the plate with your sample.
  • Small solid objects, such as fingertips, coins, or paper currency, may be gently pressed against the agar in the Petri dish.
  • If a swab will be used to obtain the sample, apply the swab to the source by pressing firmly and rolling the swab repeatedly, so as to pick up as large a sample as possible. If the surface of the sample source is dry, the sterile swab, may first be moistened by lifting the lid of the agar plate just enough to insert the swab and soaking up some of the condensed moisture on the inside of the lid. Once you have obtained the sample, inoculate your plate by streaking the swab gently but firmly across the surface of the solidified agar in a zigzag pattern. Be sure to streak within the boundaries of the quadrant lines drawn on the bottom of the plate to prevent cross-contamination. Discard used swabs after soaking them in bleach solution for at least ten minutes.
Repeat Steps 4 and 5 for the remaining quadrants of the first plate and all of the quadrants on the next two plates.
Watch the folllowing video on how to apply Parafilm<sup>®</sup> to a Petri dish:

Seal the gap between the two halves of each Petri dish using Parafilm®. Parafilm® is a stretchy, waxy material. To apply the Parafilm®, remove the paper backing, press one end of the Parafilm® against the Petri dish, stretch, and apply pressure (Figure 4 ). If one square of Parafilm® is insufficient to seal the gap, additional squares may be applied.
Invert the plates so that the side containing the agar is on top and the lid faces down.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Opening and stretching Parafilm and applying it onto the edge of a closed Petri dish.
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Opening and stretching Parafilm and applying it onto the edge of a closed Petri dish.

pageData.text: Remove your gloves and throw them in the trash. Wash and dry your hands.
Make observations daily on Days 2–5. To observe growth on a plate, turn the plate right-side up, and view the growth through the clear plastic lid.
Caution: Do not open the plates. Doing so may risk contamination with microbes that could potentially cause disease.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Photograph each plate on each day of observation. To photograph, place each plate, face up on a piece of white paper with your name, the date of the observation, and the label from each plate. Place two plates in each photo. Record your observations of each plate daily after photographing it. Describe the appearance of each plate in detail. Record your observations into Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will simulate the spread of an infectious disease by <button class='glossary-text'>fomite</button> transmission using 7 volunteers, and cups of water and acid solution. After completing the simulation, you will use the final pH of each participant’s solution to determine which participants were infected and who was patient zero.

pages.title: Internal Anatomy
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Modeling the Spread of an Infectious Disease

pageData.text: Arrange the eight plastic cups in a line on your work surface.
Pour the entire 15-mL bottle of hydrochloric acid into one of the plastic cups. The acid in this cup represents an infectious disease.
Use the 25-mL graduated cylinder to measure 15 mL of water. Add the water to one of the empty cups.
Repeat Step 3 until all eight plastic cups are filled.
Rearrange the order of the cups but note which cup contains the acid.
Gather your seven activity participants and record their names in Data Table 2.
Warn your participants that any of the cups may contain a strong acid. They must be very careful when handling the solutions during this activity.

Ask them to each take one of the filled plastic cups. Take the remaining plastic cup for yourself. Note which participant takes the acid solution. This participant now represents someone who is infected with an infectious disease.

Let the participants know that they are going to model the transmission of a disease by exchanging some of their cup’s contents with that of other participants, and that one participant is already “infected.”
Instruct the participants to randomly partner up with another participant.

Instruct the participants that one member of each partnership will pour the entire contents of their cup into their partner’s cup. Then the partner with the full cup will pour half of their cup’s contents back into their partner’s empty cup. Every participant’s cup, including yours, should have the same amount of liquid as before the activity started.
Repeat Steps 5 and 6 two more times. For each round, make sure participants partner with someone they have not partnered with before.
Take the Bogen Universal Indicator and add five drops of indicator to each participant’s cup, including yours. Gently swirl or stir the contents to disperse the indicator.
Record the color of each cup in Data Table 2. Use the indicator chart in Figure 7 to determine and record the pH of each cup.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Bogen Universal Indicator

pageData.text: Ask each participant to recall which other participants they partnered with, working backwards from the last round to the first round. Record the names of each partner in Data Table 2.
Repeat Step 9 for each participant, including you.
The initial “infected” cup containing the acid solution had a very low pH. Water has a neutral pH. Share this information with your participants.

Ask the participants to use the pH values and partner histories you recorded to determine the identity of the original infected participant, or “Patient Zero.” You already know the identity of Patient Zero, but do not reveal this answer until your participants have come up with their own answer.
Once your participants come to a conclusion and you have shared the answer with them, record the identity of Patient Zero in Data Table 2.

text: Dispose of the solutions from Activity 2 down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

To dispose of nutrient <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> plates, put on the PPE (safety goggles, gloves, and a lab apron), ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a container large enough to hold all four plates with bleach solution.
Without opening the plates, remove the Parafilm® seals.
Then, while holding each plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the plate, and separate the two halves of the Petri dish.
Remove your gloves, and wash and dry your hands.

pageData.text: Allow the plates to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: Then, while wearing the PPE, pour out the bleach, and discard the disinfected plates in the garbage.
Remove your gloves. Wash and dry your hands.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: Was any growth observed on the control plate? What would growth on the control plate indicate about the aseptic technique used? How might it affect interpretation of results obtained from the fomite samples collected? Describe another situation in which it would be desirable to use aseptic technique.
Were individual colonies distinguishable on any of the plates? If so, which? Describe the appearance of the colonies and count how many colonies were in each quadrant on each plate.
Which fomite sample provided the most abundant growth? Which provided the greatest number of different types of microbial growth? Did these results match those predicted?

What microbial types are likely to be present in each of your fomite samples? Of these, which is/are most likely to grow on the nutrient agar medium used in this investigation? Which is/are probably not culturable under the conditions used? Explain your answers.

Although macroscopic observations of microbial growth can provide much valuable information, microbiologists often follow such observations with microscopic analysis. What information might one learn by using a microscope? What are some additional factors to test in trying to identify an unknown microbe obtained from the environment?

This activity simulated how infectious diseases are spread. Which step(s) in the activity simulated the actual spreading of the disease? What would this step(s) look like if the participants were spreading a real disease?
Who was Patient Zero? How were your participants able to determine the identity of Patient Zero?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of microbe classification. Microbes can be acellular or cellular. Acellular microbes can either contain nucleic acids (DNA/RNA) or not. Acellular microbes with nucleic acids include bacteriophage that infect bacteria, viruses that infect eukaryotic cells, and viroids that infect plants. Acellular microbes without nucleic acids include prions that infect animals such as humans, cows and sheep. Cellular microbes may or may not have a nucleus. Cellular microbes without a nucleus are prokaryotes. Pro meaning before and kary meaning nucleus. They are unicellular and lack membrane-bound organelles. Examples of prokaryotes include archaea and bacteria. Cellular microbes with a nucleus are eukaryotes. Eu meaning true and kary meaning nucleus. They have membrane-bound organelles. Examples of eukaryotes include algae, protozoa, fungi, plants and animals.
pageData.desc: Figure 1: A diagram of microbe classification. Microbes can be acellular or cellular. Acellular microbes can either contain nucleic acids (DNA/RNA) or not. Acellular microbes with nucleic acids include bacteriophage that infect bacteria, viruses that infect eukaryotic cells, and viroids that infect plants. Acellular microbes without nucleic acids include prions that infect animals such as humans, cows and sheep. Cellular microbes may or may not have a nucleus. Cellular microbes without a nucleus are prokaryotes. Pro meaning before and kary meaning nucleus. They are unicellular and lack membrane-bound organelles. Examples of prokaryotes include archaea and bacteria. Cellular microbes with a nucleus are eukaryotes. Eu meaning true and kary meaning nucleus. They have membrane-bound organelles. Examples of eukaryotes include algae, protozoa, fungi, plants and animals.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: An agar plate with many small, circular colonies present.

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, set up the work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, examine the external dorsal surface and the inside of mouth of the specimen. In Activity 2, remove the skin from the abdomen and throat of the specimen, cut through the body wall and expose the internal organs. In Activity 3, examine the digestive organs of the specimen. In Activity 4, examine the heart of the specimen. In Activity 5, remove the digestive tract of the specimen. Then, examine urinary system organs and reproductive organs of the specimen. In Activity 6, remove the skin and muscle from the dorsal head of the specimen. Then, remove the cranium and examine the nervous system organs of the specimen.
Figure 3: Photograph of cooled, melted nutrient agar being poured into a Petri dish with the lid lifted.
Figure 4: A swab streaking the surface of agar in a petri dish
Figure 5: Diagram of a petri dish sectioned into four quadrants with one of the quadrants labeled
Figure 6: Opening and stretching Parafilm and applying it onto the edge of a closed Petri dish.
pageData.content: Figure 6. Applying parafilm to an agar plate

data.title: Agar
data.content: A jelly-like substance to which nutrients can be added to serve as a general-purpose medium for bacteria and other cells

data.title: Aseptic technique
data.content: A set of procedures for handling microbes that is aimed at avoiding contamination

data.title: Colony
data.content: An aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely-adhering cells

data.title: Culture
data.content: A growth of microbes in a prepared nutrient medium

data.title: Disinfection
data.content: A process that eliminates many or all pathogenic microorganisms, except bacterial spores, on inanimate objects

data.title: Fomite
data.content: An inanimate object that transmits infectious diseases from microbes found on its surface

data.title: Free-living
data.content: Describes organisms that do not depend on a host organism for survival

data.title: Inoculating
data.content: Introducing microbes into a culture media so that it can grow

data.title: Macroscopic
data.content: Can be seen with the unaided eye

data.title: Medium (media)
data.content: The substrate within or on which the microbes will grow; plural, media

data.title: Microbe
data.content: A broad term used to describe a diverse group of organism and infectious particles

data.title: Microbiologist
data.content: A biologist who specializes in the study of microbes

data.title: Non-culturable
data.content: Describes bacteria that are in a state of very low metabolic activity and do not divide on conventional media

data.title: Opportunistic
data.content: Describes pathogens that are generally free-living , but can cause disease if given the opportunity

data.title: Parasite
data.content: An organism that obtains nutrients from another host organism

data.title: Saprophyte
data.content: An organism that decomposes dead organic material to obtain nutrients

data.title: Sterile
data.content: To be free from bacteria or other living microorganisms
